citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, the safe (located in the office outside of the main tiger holding area) which contains
controlled drugs (i.e., tranquilizers) that are supposed to be utilized in case of an emergency/animal escape, was broken
(the staff was not able open the safe) and not working for months. If a tiger were to escape, lack of immediate access to
tranquilizers to dart the animal would create a safety hazard for all persons in the vicinity of the animal, as well as the
animal itself as it could be injured and/or encounter forced use of a fatalistic option to immobilize it. Each exhibitor shall
establish and maintain a program of adequate veterinary care that include the availability of appropriate equipment and
services to comply with the provisions of this subchapter. The General Curator and Property Manager stated they would
replace the safe soon.
Correct by: December 11, 2024

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection there were expired drugs (located in the medicine cabinet for all the animals maintained at the
facility) which could have been used on the animals at any time – Nuflor (Florfenicol, lot # 2673102) which expired in June
2024 and Dexium-SP (dexamethasone sodium phosphate, lot #3F009) which expired in October 2024. This was
confirmed with the facility representatives that were present. Usage of expired drugs can cause injury and/or suffering to
the animals and are ineffective for their intended use. Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate
veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by: November 30, 2024

The contingency plan did not receive an annual review. This was confirmed with the General Curator during records
review. Failure of an annual review can lead to outdated information, and can negatively impact the health and well-being
of the animals due to a staff that is unprepared to mitigate the hazards and dangers associated with the identified risks.
The plan must be reviewed by the exhibitor at least on an annual basis to ensure that it adequately addresses the criteria
listed in paragraph (a) of section 2.134. Each licensee must maintain documentation of their contingency plans and
annual reviews, and documentation must be made available to APHIS upon request. In addition, when there are changes
to the plan as a result of the annual review, exhibitors must provide training for their personnel regarding their roles and
responsibilities within 30 days of making the changes, as per 2.134(c).
Correct by: December 11, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
